awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: Modeling Precolonial and Colonial Niche Construction
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2).

This project will undertake research to better understand how and why humans modify their natural environments, and what happens when they stop doing so. Humans have had far-reaching effects on the environment across the planet, so it is important to research the specific demographic and economic drivers of these impacts. Archaeology can provide a useful means to address these issues, as the past is full of case studies which can be analyzed to understand such activities and trace the history of environmental impacts. Such research can also inform solutions to environmental degradation and contribute to understanding the environmental impacts of human population changes and how different economic systems can lead to either ecological destruction or long-term health.

This project consists of both computational modeling and archaeological data analysis to better understand human environmental impacts. The modeling will contribute to theory about environmental modification by building computer simulations to investigate the impacts of human population size and economic forces on the environment. The analysis will evaluate environmental data from a time of colonial settlement and integration into a new global economy. This analysis will test the predictions of the model and attempt to determine the ecological impacts of colonization and how the environment was impacted by resulting changes in forest management, farming, and hunting. The results of this research will contribute to knowledge of environmental modification and natural resource management, both in theory and in terms of the history of environmental changes that have led us to the present.  This information can help researchers to better understand how to improve the ecology of our planet today.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The colonization of New England by Europeans in the 17th century brought widespread and impactful changes to the region. The overall human population declined precipitously due to Indigenous demographic collapse caused by epidemic disease, colonial conflict, socioeconomic marginalization, and acts of genocide. The region was also rapidly integrated into a trans-Atlantic market economy while the environment itself was changed due to several additional factors. All these changes were likely to have affected the sustainability of natural resource use and management in New England.

 

In this project, I employed both agent-based modeling and zooarchaeological analyses to investigate the effects of European colonization on natural resource use in New England, specifically focusing on white-tailed deer. White-tailed deer were hunted for millennia by Indigenous peoples but were commodified in the colonial period as their hides were used in the leathermaking industry. Deer also thrive in environments modified by people, permitting insight into environmental change through the analysis of deer demography. As part of this research, I built an agent-based simulation model of the interactions between people, deer, and controlled burning of the landscape to explore human impacts on resources and the environment. I also analyzed animal bones from two archaeological sites in the Connecticut River Valley to infer changes in deer demography before and after European colonization using zooarchaeological methods.

 

My results suggest that:

1)    Human population decline can lead to reduced environmental impacts overall, but per capita increases if people seek to maximize deer harvests through the use of fire in ecosystem engineering.

2)    Deer populations declined in 17th century New England due to both increased hunting pressure and reduced environmental productivity. Hunting pressure likely increased due to commodification of deerskins. Reduced environmental productivity may have followed from reduced burning by Indigenous people, but could also have resulted from increased land clearance by European farmers or the onset of the Little Ice Age climate period.

 
These results contribute to scholarly understanding of natural resource management and environmental modification in several ways. First, they illuminate the effects of colonialism and market integration on the sustainability of natural resource use. Second, they contribute to further theorization of not only niche construction theory, but concepts of resource depression, costly signaling, and sustainability. Third, they validate a useful zooarchaeological approach to reconstructing white-tailed deer demography and assessing the drivers of population change in the species. Finally, they provide much needed zooarchaeological data from New England as this region has few well-analyzed animal bone assemblages. This project not only contributes to an improved academic understanding of sustainable natural resource use and management, but can help to provide useful insights for policymakers today.
